column1: #text=        Diaphragmatic hernia Olya Polishchuk Mary Wyers, M.D.Children's Memorial Hospital  Abstract  Newborn with respiratory distress.

column4: Publication Date: 2004-06-14                History  Newborn with respiratory distress.

column1: #text=  Findings 3/23/04 - Air-filled structures in the thorax are consistant with herniated loops of bowel.
#text=Nasogastric tube loops into left hemithorax indicating herniated stomach.
#text=Loops of bowel are positioned in the abdomen.
#text=Mediastinum is now in the correct location.

#text=   Diagnosis  Diaphragmatic hernia    Differential Diaphragmatic eventration, congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation,   Discussion The two major types of defects in the diaphragm that can result in diaphragmatic hernia (DH) are: hernia through foramen of Bochdalek (posterolateral), hernia through foramen of Morgagni (anterior).
#text=Most common herniation of abdominal contents occurs through foramen of Bochdalek.
#text=The small intestine is herniated 90% of the cases and the colon and stomach in greater than 50%.
#text=80% of Bochdalek hernias are on the left, and 20% are on the right.
#text=Morgagni hernias are more common on the right.
#text=The neonate with DH will present with symptoms varying from tachypnea to acute respiratory distress.
#text=The treatment is surgical, and there is controversy over the appropriate timing of surgery.
#text=The high morbidity and mortality is associated not only with pulmonary hypoplasia secondary to the mass effect, but also to severe pulmonary hypertension which results.
#text=Many of these patients require ECMO in the first few weeks of life.
#text=DH is commonly associated with cardiac, genitourinary, neural tube development defects.
#text=  References  Kuhn, J.P., Slovis, T.L., Haller, J.O., CAFFEY'S PEDIATRIC DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING, Elsevier, Inc., 2004, 58-63.
